results.description:
Our post-Halloween selection received these intriguing reviews.

Our communal obsessions seem to have shifted–at least in the area of supernatural beings: Angels are passe, the Devil is "in.'' Andrew Delbanco calls for his resurrection; psychoanalyst Carl Goldberg uses the phrase "speaking with the devil'' as a metaphor for his work with malevolent patients; Elaine Pagels scrutinizes Satan's roots. Even Philip Roth's Mickey Sabbath bears a striking resemblance to the proud, rebellious, orgiastic Prince of Darkness. And now we are treated to his image in art. Link, a scholar of Elizabethan drama, considers the development of Satan in Western sculpture and painting: the supposed impact of the hairy, horned Pan; the role of the Egyptian dwarf deity, Bes; the addition of black bat-wings in the 14th century, in the work of Giotto. But, according to Link, the Devil never attained the power in visual art that he did in literature. Just as well–he is perhaps a creature who flourishes best in the imagination. ©1996, Kirkus Associates, LP.


A provocative study of the iconography of Hell's monarch. A scholarly work which covers the period of medieval and Renaissance from the 4th to the 16th centuries. THE TIMES [London] From Kirkus Reviews

Some members will be attending this optional field trip after lunch. Feel free to join us.:

Fine Arts M.F.A. Open Studios Showcase Work of More than 90 Artists

Pratt Institute's Fine Arts Department will host MFA Open Studios and MFA Performances. These events will showcase more than 90 international artists who are currently enrolled in Pratt's Fine Arts Masters program. Areas of concentration include: Painting and Drawing, Sculpture, Photography, Printmaking, and New Forms. MFA Performances, a unique student-led event that provides an audience for students working in performance, will take place the same evening at Flushing Studios.

https://www.pratt.edu/academics/school-of-art/graduate-school-of-art/graduate-fine-arts/pal/

results.description:
PLEASE READ ALL OF THIS VERY CAREFULLY

***YOU MUST PAY BEFORE YOU RSVP***

****TO REGISTER AND PAY FOR THE EVENT CLICK HERE****

By popular demand, we're headed back to The Big Apple! We have a great preset itinerary with plenty of time to take it slow, get more time shooting, and get more instruction.

                                                   ©Steve Rosenbach


On this trip, we'll do both daylight and nighttime photography. You might call this one a "Brooklyn Sandwich," great photo opportunities from the Brooklyn side of East River, sandwiched between two photo-licious slices of Manhattan.  YUMM!

Once we arrive in NYC at 7th Avenue and 27th Street a little after 12:30 pm, we'll fuel up with some lunch for the rest of our adventure.

After lunch, we'll get out our cameras to photograph the cityscape there. The park is an urban oasis with great views of several iconic buildings, including the Flatiron Building, New York's first skyscraper, and Empire State Building a few blocks to the north. 

From there, we'll hop onto the subway and take a ride to the DUMBO section (Down Under Manhattan Bridge Overpass​) of Brooklyn, where we'll spend time in Main Street Park photographing Manhattan Bridge, Brooklyn Bridge, and the lower Manhattan skyline, before, during, and after sunset. AWESOME!

After a quick dinner, once again, by popular demand, we'll walk to Manhattan across the Brooklyn Bridge after nightfall, taking plenty of time to photograph the huge gothic towers, the spiderweb-like structure of the cable support system, and amazing, up-close views of Manhattan. No need to rush.
Plenty of great Kodak...I mean...digital moments!

Once on the Manhattan side of the Bridge, we'll once again duck into the subway and take a quick ride to Greenwich Village in order to photograph the spectacularly-illuminated Washington Square Arch.  

Finally, about 10:30 pm, after a late dinner at 9pm, we'll walk to the Megabus pickup location for our trip back to White Marsh.

If you went to the THE NOCTURNAL NEW YORK NIGHTTIME PHOTOGRAPHY PHENOMENON on August 29th, your fee for this event is ONLY $59

results.description:
Besides our usual discussion, at this Meetup I'll share some highlights from World Fantasy Con (which I'm attending November 5th-8th), as well as discussing other upcoming SF cons and writer events. 

Meet to share and discuss SF and fantasy writing, books, films, TV shows, the writing process, the publishing industry, etc. with other SF and fantasy writers (both published and unpublished).  We usually have a long and lively discussion, followed by critiques of stories or chapters (if any) that members brought along.  We don't always have stories to critique, but we usually enjoy having hours worth of discussion, so let us know near the beginning of the Meetup if you brought something to have critiqued so we don't use up all our time talking -- time flies when you're having fun!

Further details or topics for this Meetup may be announced later.

As usual, you can bring a chapter or short story for the group to critique, but it's by no means necessary.  If you do bring your MS, try to bring enough paper copies for everyone attending to have one, and if you want us to write comments or corrections on it, then please double-space it.  We usually ask the author to read it aloud (unless you're shy), which is very helpful, because you'd be surprised how often you don't catch your own mistakes until you read your manuscript aloud for the first time! 

For the manuscript (MS) critiques, length is not set in stone, but suggested length is 1500 words, maximum length 3000 words. In pages (Times 12 point font), 1500 words is just under five pages double spaced, or about three pages single-spaced (but you should always double-space to allow room for people to write comments or corrections!)  Don't worry if your MS is longer than 1500 words, you can still bring it, but please keep it under 3,000 words.

For more guidelines on critiques, see http://www.meetup.com/The-Woodbridge-Science-Fiction-Fantasy-Writers-Meetup/about/
results.name: Share and discuss writing with other SF and fantasy writers

results.description:
Fellow run chugger, Francisco, is organizing this event with his meetup group. They'll start the run/crawl at 1:00 in Long Island City at the East River Ferry stop and will finish it in Bushwick. Check it out!


-------------------------------------------------------------------

Thanks Michael for letting me post this event here. I have also posted this on my outdoors meetup where I have been posting this runs like this for a few years. 

About the event:


This is a really fun event that I do a few times a year in different parts of the city. The idea is to stop every mile or so at pub and have a pint of beer. You can either run, walk or crawl from pub to pub. I will be running the whole six miles. (Hopefully!)

Where did I get this idea?

My friend Dolgio read an article about a guy run a marathon while chugging beer every few miles so she thought it would be a brilliant idea to do it for her birthday in November about 5 years ago in Queens. I felt like this should be repeated at least one more time and I have been doing this every year sine adding different courses and changing the bars around.

Can I join in later?

Sure, I will update the meetup letting people know what bar we are at. Also I will post my number on the comments section. You can then either text me if you can't find us or send me a Glympse request. Glympse is an app that will show my GPS location for up to four hours after you request it using my phone number.

The Plan:

Meet at the East River Ferry landing Center Blvd in LIC. I will probably take the ferry myself from Dumbo. The north bound ferry lands in LIC at 12:55 pm. The southbound ferry at 1:05pm. I will be on the north bound ferry. Here is the ferry schedule:

http://www.eastriverferry.com/RoutesSchedules/

We will start running at 1:10pm unless the ferry gets delayed.

The 7 train is not running this weekend if you want to get there by train. Your best bet is to take the ferry. The ferry stops at 34th street and Wall Street in Manhattan. Dumbo, South Williamsburg, North Williamsburg and Breakpoint in Brooklyn. 

You can also take Citi Bike. 

If you want to take the train you can take the N or Q train to Queensboro plaza and then catch the shuttle to Vernon Blvd, run, walk or use Citi Bike.

You can also take the G train to 21 street - Van Alst and walk on 47th Avenue to Center Blvd. Make a left on Center Blvd and walk for about 500 feet until you reach the ferry landing. 

 • Leg 1:

Destination: Jungle Cafe - t.b.d.

Address: 966 Manhattan Ave

Distance: 1.4 miles 

The course: From the Ferry Landing we run to Center Blvd. Make a left on Center. Right on 51st Ave then left on Jackson Ave then we get on the bridge. After the bridge right on Eagle St and left on Manhattan. We will stop at Jungle Cafe for a quick bite and then get drinks at t.b.d. They are almost next to each other so it is not worth making it a leg from one place to the other. 

 • Leg 2:

Destination: Berry Park

Address: 4 Berry St 

Distance: 0.8 miles 

The course: Left on Franklin until you hit N 14th St. Left on N 14th St until you reach Berry St. The pub will be on your right.

• Leg 3:

Destination: Bia

Address: 67 South 6th St 

Distance: 1 mile

The course: We go South on Berry St until we hit South 6th St. Make a right on S 6th St. 

- Leg 4:

Destination: Lady Jay's

Address: 633 Grand St

Distance: 1.1 miles

The course: We go east on South 4th St then left on Borinquen Pl and then right on Grand St until we reach 633. 

• Leg 5:

Destination: Pine Box Rock Shop 

Address: 12 Grattan St 

Distance: 1.3 miles 

The course: East on Grand St then right on Morgan Ave and then right Grattan St. The bar will be on your left.

• Leg 6:

Destination: Left Hand Path

Address: 89 Wyckoff Ave

Distance: 1 mile 

The course: East on Grattan St, right on Morgan Ave, Morgan Ave turns in Wilson Ave after flushing stay on Wilson until you reach Starr St. Left on Starr St until Suydam St. Make a left on Suydam and then a right when you reach Wyckoff Ave. 

Click here for the map on Google Maps

Picture of the course this year:

results.description:
PLEASE RSVP RESPONSIBLY.  YOU WILL BE REQUIRED TO RE-CONFIRM YOUR RSVP WHEN WE GET CLOSER TO THE EVENT DAY.

YOU MUST BE 21 OR OLDER TO ATTEND THIS EVENT, AND YOU ABSOLUTELY MUST BRING YOUR ID. NO ID, AND YOU CANNOT JOIN THE EVENT.  

So, who wants to spend a Saturday afternoon at a full day, karaoke marathon?!?! Seven hours of fun, laughs and songs for only $14!! We will start at 1 pm, and can sing, non-stop until 8 pm.

We are allowed to bring in food (we can even order delivery).  However, you cannot bring in any outside drinks.  Not even water, but they provide free pitchers of water there.

And don't say "I can't sing", because I can guarantee you that most people who come to these are not winning American Idol any time soon! Well, maybe Vanessa.  But, it's all about having fun and a few laughs!! Trust me, it's a lot of fun, and everyone usually ends up singing along, so you're not totally in the spotlight.  Maybe that's why they have the word "Duet" in the name of the place.

Please, go to www.karaokeduet.com and check out the song selection.  They have the song codes, so write down at least a few and come prepared to start singing right away!! But there are songs that they have in a book of "newly added" songs that aren't yet up on their website.  So if you don't see your favorite, it may still be available!  Last time we were there, the group sang almost 100 songs in total!!

In order to make sure that everyone gets equal opportunity to sing, the way we're going to run this event is that everyone can add whatever song (with the code) that they want to sing to a sign-up sheet that I will maintain.  Then I will add the songs to the queue so that it is evenly spread out.  With this in mind, it would be beneficial to look at the song list online in advance, and come with your list (including the song codes), so you at least have a few to start off with.

REMEMBER, YOU MUST BRING YOUR ID TO  SHOW THAT YOU ARE OVER 21! NO ID, NO ENTRY.
results.name: Sing Your Heart Out - KARAOKE!!!

results.description:
Whether you are visiting our beautiful city, coming from a lesson, or just have the day off...come on out and hit with us! We are a group of tennis enthusiast of 2.5 to 4.0 levels that have the fundamental parts of the game down and like to hit against different styles of play.


WHY PLAY HERE?

Well, first of all it is a nice serene location (i.e. no basketball courts, grandstands, or any other type of distraction). Secondly, consider the cost options to play else elsewhere in-and-around the city...


1) unless you have endless tennis competitors on your roll-a-dex, you'll need a web-based database/system to find people. Most of these tennis databases/systems charge in different ways. Fact, Meetup charges me a premium every month because of the member pool size and this has to be  prepaid just to keep the group alive.

2) if you play anywhere in NYC, you will need a permit which will currently cost you $15 for a single day (or $200 for a yearly). To be more specific, these two options really only entitle you to one hour of singles play (vs. 2 hours here), meaning your partner will also need a permit.

3) new balls are provided at the beginning of each day. Typical extra-duty balls run about $3 per can off-the-shelf, so if you are an avid player...you'll save time and money running around picking-up tennis balls.

4) if someone were to break a string, or you just want to try a different racquet for an evaluation (i.e. lighter weight, bigger head, tighter strings, etc), racquets are available at no addition cost.

5) seasonally "clean" courts. Throughout the year tennis courts pile up with blowing leaves, pollen, acorns, etc. I get here early every session to ensure the courts are clean. I do this with a battery-powered blower and if any body knows anything about batteries...its that they don't last! Each time I have to replace one (which only does one court), it cost me nearly $100 for each.

6) portions of fee here actually go repairing the courts and/or nets. Case-and-point the cement required to fill cracks which was recently done by myself.

7) there are port-a-potty's and 2 drinking fountains available for all to use

8) no dress code required like some places...but proper edict is appreciated


9) based on the talent that signup, I may ask people to move around to establish a competitive session for all those involved


Hopefully this addresses all those questions like: is it free or why does it cost.

WAYS TO RSVP...

Within Meetup, just click RSVP for the time slot that works best with your schedule and be resposible to attend. You can prepay (eliminating the need to remember to carry cash) a number of ways:

Reserve via PayPal ([masked]) vs. cash and select friends (not service) to avoid additional PayPal fees

OR

1. Create an account at MindBodyOnline scheduling software:

https://clients.mindbodyonline.com/classic/home?studioid=152916

2. Decide which package you want to purchase:

1 session = $25; Use Promo Code = T15TS1 

3 sessions @ $20 = $60; Use Promo Code = T15TS3 

6 sessions @ $17 = $102; Use Promo Code = T15TS6 

10 sessions @ $15 = $150; Use Promo Code = T15TS10

3. Go to the Online Store and before Checking Out; APPLY the Promo code of your choice to receive discounted pricing.  

4. Go to the Day and Time of your choice to RSVP your attendance

WEATHER

Weather is always an unpredictable thing but remember, just because a forecast says 30% chance of showers...that also means 70% chance of no showers. Also with the 30% it may be in your area, but not where the courts are. Lastly, if it does sprinkle...we have the necessary equipment to dry them.

http://www.accuweather.com/en/us/new-york-ny/10032/hourly-weather-forecast/3727_pc

DIRECTIONS

We are directly south of the George Washington Bridge right on the Hudson River. Best ways to get there are A train, M4 or M98 bus, biking along the river or driving and parking on Riverside Drive behind the Presbyterian hospital (being the less favorite).

http://www.google.com/maps/@40.8494798,-73.9430776,16z?hl=en

(walking via 181 street subway stop)

1. Take A Train to 181st Street Station (sit in the back of the train).

2. Walk West on 181st Street which turns into Plaza Lafayette.

3. Make a Right, on Riverside Drive to the light green Pedestrian Crossover Bridge.

4. Cross the pedestrian bridge and follow the ramp down proceeding toward the GW Bridge which zigzags (crossing over the railroad tracks), and down the hill.

5. Arrive at the courts on your left.

Please plan an additional 15 minutes for weekend subway schedule delays and note its takes an additional 15 minutes to walk from 181st Street Station to the courts, so please arrive before scheduled slot so everyone can start on time.

<a href="http://www.accuweather.com/en/us/new-york-ny/10032/hourly-weather-forecast/3727_pc"></a>

results.description:
Learn to Salsa New York Style with Yrma Arias at El Taller! This style of Salsa, "On 2", has gained popularity over the last decade in NYC. The classes will focus on the look and feel of the dance - with an emphasis on timing, footwork and partner work. Classes will provide instruction and repetition of the steps ‘Shines’, introduce the importance of the leader/follower connection, and provide practical techniques for the Latin Motion. Particular attention is paid to rhythm and musicality. This is an enjoyable class designed for people of all ages. The most important lesson is to have fun! What to bring: A great attitude and comfortable clothes and shoes that allow you to move!


When you arrive at 215 E. 99th Street, press the El T button on the intercom and we'll buzz you right in!
results.name: Beginner Salsa Dancing

results.description:
Focusing on the works of Louis-Claude de Saint-Martin, we will explore the foundations of Martinism - a mystical movement deeply rooted in the Western Esoteric Tradition.

The facilitator of the discussion will be Julian Johnson, long time member of both the Rosicrucian Order AMORC and the Traditional Martinist Order.
results.name: Learn about the Martinist Tradition

results.description:
IKEA...we love it!  Everyone can divide and conquor then meet up again at the restaurant for swedish meatballs, salmon and more, often under $5 for a well-rounded lunch.  Then check out and grab some of their wonderful sweet rolls on the way out!  The Marketplace on the lower level is crazy fun - $10 orchids, curtains, storage items to refresh a closet, new towels, everything!  Truly refreshing!  

Here's what's on my radar - the new self-charging phone pieces - pads to just lay our cell phones on without wires and it will charge them!  They have pads, lamps, bedside & living room side tables that have this feature.  Even if you don't need more stuff LOL - its a great place to go, see & dine!  And, you can replace older stuff for a fraction of most other stores to freshen up your space before the holidays.  Then, there are wonderful food options at the restaurant and the market too, including frozen foods.  This is our third year for an Ikea visit!  Their new healthy dish:  Chicken with corn and black bean salad for $4.99! Not only is it delicious, but the entire meal is just 275 calories.

The top 5 things to get at Ikea this year that are so worth the schlep!  http://www.today.com/home/5-new-ikea-products-are-so-worth-schlep-t34256?cid=eml_tsl_20150724  Also, click on the video to see the self-charging items!

Link to Ikea USA site so you can start scoping things out LOL:  http://www.ikea.com/us/en/
results.how_to_find_us: Carpoolers can meet at the LIE Exit 63 P & R and/or Exit 59 at Susan's!
results.name: IKEA Fun Day!

group.name: THRIVE - Good Times with Great Friends! (GTGF) Long Island

results.description:
Hi Design Enthusiasts! Welcome to the Bronx Interior Design & Decorating Meetup Group "DESIGN DAY" Meetup! Do you have a project in hand and want to learn design with professional advice? Our group is different from other design groups because we are all about learning to take the actual steps in learning of the design process of Interior Design! We will meet every 2nd Saturday of the month for "Design Day!". On our Design Days Meetups, you will learn to design rooms, What are the furniture and design styles, type of fabrics, do drawings, make design collages, learn to match colors realistically, and occassionally visiting furniture and material shops.

*Attention: You are taking actual interior design lessons by real interior design graduate(s) from New York's top design schools where we paid thousands-of-dollars for these classes!!!


To join us for Design Day, Join our group and RSVP for every 2nd Saturday of each month. The fee for Design Day is $25 each session. Bring 2 friends and get a free Design Day pass for yourself. You will need to make a payment here online, 24 hours prior to the meeting. Please honor your RSVPs as your payments are not refundable but you will be credited to your next meetup. Please hold a receipt of your payment for your credit.

Be sure to suggest the type of design day to your favor so I will make sure you get what you want. Don't forget to post greetings and photos of our meetups!

Note: Once we determine what we will be doing, I will email participants 24-48 hours advance on what you need to bring to each Design Day meetup.


Here are the basic materials to bring:
-You're favorite design magazine or design book
-tracing paper
-pencils (color or graphite)/ pens/ or guache paint
-8"x11"+ sketch book
-portfolio book with page inserts to put together everything you learned with us.

Some of these materials are available to use at a $10 fee each day, on top of the Meetup fee.


[For Serious Design Enthusiasts - I have Design Workshops at varying prices for beginners to learn the design process with real hands-on experience. There are 2 types of workshops. One is 'In House' workshop, you will be working at my outdoor studio in The Bronx in the spring & summer time. The second type is hands on experience with a real live client. You will be guided by me and my assistants throughout the project. Please inquire if you are interested in these 2 days or more Design Workshops. I will tailor a course for you at your budget.]


Now Let's have fun with Design Projects!


Cheers,


Monica
Director of 'The Mon Liu Design Studio & Guest House'

results.description:
This is a co-ed adult pick-up game 6v6 or 7 v7 depending on attendance. 90 minutes with two 45 minute halves. No slide tackling or rough play. We play with Pugg goals. Pinnies provided.  Shin guards are recommended.


This pick up game is hosted by Coach Moe and is free for those who attended both training sessions with him the same day, $4 for all others.


PLEASE UPDATE YOUR RSVP AT LEAST 2 HOURS BEFORE THE GAME!

• Update your RSVP by 11:30AM

• RSVPs close by 12 NOON

• No shows and those who didn't update their RSVP at least 2 hours before the game will be red carded after the second offense, which means that we have the right to edit your RSVP.

Directions by subway or bus:

2 and 3 trains to Clark St.

A and C trains to High St.


F train to York St.


N and R trains to Court St.


Weather policy:

In case of inclement weather we will send out an email to notify you at least two hours before meeting time.

What to bring:

Please note that Cadman Plaza park is a turf field. Turf shoes are preferred. Please bring water or sports drink. Please bring a ball if you have one.


By RSVP-ing YES you agree to the following:

I certify that I have no known medical or other conditions that could interfere with my participation in Williamsburg Soccer Training activities. I also understand and accept that the practice of soccer, both indoor and outdoor, involves certain risks of physical injury. Therefore, I, individually, hereby release and discharge, Williamsburg Soccer Training Organizer and Assistant Organizers from any and all claims, actions, damages, losses, liabilities, costs and expenses of any kind whatsoever, including but not limited to any claims of negligence, arising out of, resulting from, by reason of, or in connection with my participation in any of Williamsburg Soccer Training programs or activities.

results.description:
All levels practice. Coached by Granger.

This practice is about water polo. Emphasis is on playing and learning the game by playing. Some of us have been playing since childhood. Others have picked it up as adults. We're friendly and inclusive, but we play hard.

Requirements:

-You have to join New York Recreation. $75 for 6 months for access to all rec centers and pools in the city. If you're under 25, you pay $25 for 1 year. http://www.nycgovparks.org/programs/recreation-centers/membership

-Beginners are welcome, but you must be a good swimmer.

-You MUST bring a lock for a gym locker.

-You should bring an athletic bathing suit, goggles, and a towel. Bring a swim cap if you have long hair.
results.how_to_find_us: We'll be around the lobby and lockers at 1:45 and we'll start warming up in the pool by 2.
results.name: BK Wets play water polo (all levels)

results.description:
SAVE THE DATE! Saturday, November 14, 2015, 2-5 pm, doors open at 1:45

Join co-hosts Bronx Climate Justice North and the Center for Urban Resilience and Environmental Sustainability of Manhattan College for a Community Forum and Discussion about Bronx Residential Buildings and Global Climate Justice!

Please take a moment to register for this free event here: http://www.eventbrite.com/e/made-in-the-bronx-green-buildings-green-jobs-tickets-18912789663

Climate change – caused largely by heat-trapping greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions from fossil fuels (coal, oil, natural gas) – threatens our economy, infrastructure, public health, food & water, and NYC’s future. The year 2015 is on track to be the warmest on record.

Buildings account for close to 72% of U.S. electricity use, a significant percentage of GHGs, and contribute to high asthma rates in the Bronx. We need a rapid and just shift OFF fossil fuels and ON to a 100% renewable energy economy by 2030. Join us to learn how we can “green” our residential buildings. Our speakers will focus on the transition to renewables (solar, wind, geothermal), energy conservation, boiler conversions, and exciting initiatives in the Bronx to build a green, local workforce, and green housing for all.

CONFIRMED SPEAKERS:

Moderator: Dr. Yelda Hangun-Balkir, Director, Manhattan College Center for Urban Resilience and Environmental Sustainability (CURES)
Keynote Speaker: Ray Figueroa, President, NYC Community Garden Coalition
Lisa DiCaprio: Professor of Social Sciences, NYU
Chris Neidl: Director, Here Comes Solar, Solar One
John Reilly, Executive Director, Fordham Bedford Housing Corporation
Migdalia Taveras: Director, BEST Academy, Sustainable South Bronx

Co-sponsors [in progress]: Bronx Climate Justice, South Bronx Unite, Riverdale-Yonkers Society for Ethical Culture, NW Bx for Change, 350NYC, New York Solar Energy Society (NYSES), Save the Putnam Trail, Sierra Club NYC, Northwest Bronx Community & Clergy Coalition (NWBCCC), Bronx Council for Environmental Quality (BCEQ)

WHERE: Smith Auditorium, Manhattan College, 4513 Manhattan College Parkway in central Riverdale neighborhood of the Bronx; take the #1 (Bronx-bound) to the last stop-242nd St/Van Cortlandt Park; from Broadway, walk west on W. 242nd St, bearing left onto Manhattan College Parkway; the campus will be on your right; take the first available path onto campus, make your way to Smith Auditorium, in the center of campus.

This event is FREE and open to the public. Please register at the Eventbrite page link above, thank you!
results.name: Made in the Bronx: Green Buildings, Green Jobs

results.description:
The Wild Side is all about enjoying the outdoors.

This Sunday we will be hiking the Deserted Village of Feltville in the Watchung Reservation.  

I know that it's super short notice, but if you can make it definitely join us :)

Trail: We will start by going down to visit the Deserted Village of Feltville.  We will then follow the History Trail, that will take us around a loop of the Watchung Reservation (see our course drawn in green below).

Difficulty: Moderate.  The majority of the trail features moderate inclines, followed by moderate declines.

results.description:
Have you ever taken a tour of the secrets of the Metropolitan Museum of Art? Well, that’s exactly what you’re going to get here. We’re sharing all the little known facts we know about the museum. This is less about the unparalleled art collection, for which guides abound, but more about the tidbits that make the building like none other in the city. It’s about its architecture, its rich history, and the hidden gems to look out for on your first, second, and umpteenth visits to the museum.  

$10 contribution will be collected in cash when you arrive. This will also cover your admission into the museum. 

** This will be our first "official" meetup. Am looking forward to meeting you!**

November 13, 2015: One fun fact >>


Did You Know The American Wing was Once a Free Standing Building? (Just one of many fun facts you'll learn on our First Meetup!)


The neoclassical facade of the American Wing, curiously built into the wall of Engelhard Court (Gallery 700), was actually a  freestanding building facing an exterior garden for fifty years, until it was enclosed in 1980. The facade was rescued from the Branch Bank of the United States, located on Wall Street, before that building’s demolition in the 1920’s.

results.description:
THIS EVENT IS SOLD OUT. IF YOU DIDN"T PURCHASE AN TICKET ON EVENTBRITE, PLEASE DON'T COME.

DISCOVER THE GILDED AGE MANSIONS OF UPPER FIFTH AVENUE’S GOLD COAST ON OUT PROFESSIONALS’ WALKING TOUR AND MIXER.

On Saturday afternoon, November 14, you are invited to join Members and friends of Out Professionals for “Millionaires’ Row: The Walking Tour and Mixer.” Afterwards, we adjourn to an Upper East Side watering hole. Don’t miss out: This is the last OP walking tour until spring!

In perhaps the Gilded Age’s greatest scandal, Millionaires’ Row architect Stanford White, above left, dallied with showgirl Evelyn Nesbit, wife of millionaire Harry K. Thaw, right. Thaw gunned down White during the premiere of “Mam’zelle Champagne” at his rooftop theater on Madison Square.

Following the creation of Central Park in 1857, homes for American tycoons with aristocratic yearnings — European-style homes designed to project power, wealth and stature — began to line the park’s eastern border. The survival of so many of these Gilded Age mansions is a tribute to Fifth Avenue’s enduring allure.

Of course The American Dream had its dark side, and “Millionaires’ Row: The Walking Tour and Mixer” does not stint on other Gold Coast scandals and crimes.

Tour highlights include:

• The Henry Clay Frick Mansion, built by a powerful financier and industrialist whom Andrew Carnegie called “The Man.” (Frick’s underground bowling alley survives.)

• The James Buchanan Duke Mansion. Upon the death of American Tobacco’s “Buck” Duke, the mansion passed to his only child, gossip-column favorite Doris Duke.

• Harkness House, built for Stephen V. Harkness, the silent but second-largest shareholder in Standard Oil, the combine that made John D. Rockefeller the world’s richest man.

• Payne Whitney House, designed by Stanford White. Having seduced Nesbit, “The Girl in the Red Velvet Swing,” White met his death at the hands of her young husband before he could see his masterpiece completed. 

Out Professionals’ private Walking Tour/Mixer series is designed for us — and you — by Joyce Gold History Tours of New York. Joyce teaches Manhattan history at New York University and the New School.

WHAT’S UP

Tour begins at 2 p.m. sharp, rain or shine. We meet in front of the Frick Collection, 1 East 70th Street, between Fifth and Madison Avenues. Subway: 6 to 68th Street/Hunter College. Nearby open-ended mixer begins about 4 p.m. Refreshments on your own.

ADMISSION

SORRY, SOLD OUT
results.name: Let's Meetup and Tour Upper Fifth Avenue!

Everything is changing. Film is no longer only being done on big screens. Television is now a place where the Hollywood bigs play. Online video is not just for vlogs. Everyone is streaming. If Content was King in 2004, in 2015…it's GOD. Join us for this look at how technology and digital has influenced how storytellers and media entrepreneurs create, market, finance and distribute their content today..and beyond! Are you ready for what comes NEXT?

PARTICIPANTS INCLUDE*:

MICAH AINSLEY BROWN, Chief Executive Officer | FILM FUNDR | www.filmfundr.com

Filmfundr enables. We value film through technology and help fund and distribute, including enabling Virtual Reality Content to be created. We help first time filmmakers, film students and established directors and individuals value & fund disruptive content. From inception to premiere and beyond, we help filmmakers bring content to screens, mobile or otherwise. We assist independent film makers and students in particular, to fulfill their film visions.

For more information on MEDIA/NEXT, visit http://medianext.eventbrite.com

results.description:
Please join us for our next monthly installment of GUY GALLERY WALK, our November editon! Here's our gallery line-up:

1st STOP: We'll meet out front of our 1st Gallery at 2:00pm 


MITCHELL-INNES & NASH (534 W 26th St) presents: KARL HAENDEL ORGANIC BEDFELLOW, FERAL OTHELLO

"What could be a better foil in understanding human evolution than everyday moments of devolution, which have remained a part of our species for thousands of years: getting cold, quenching thirst, being out of breathe. Black and white may be defined in opposition to each other but this is also what makes them inextricably linked. Our evolution is our devolution.  Our devolution is our evolution.  When we recycle, somewhere deep down inside we acknowledge the hypothetical end of Earth for our species, and when we couple, somewhere deep down inside we resist it."

A visual thread of geometric shapes ties together three groups of black-and-white drawings which contemplate this juxtaposition: primates balance atop modernist, geometric stacks; couples bend and stretch in yoga poses contained in shaped frames; still life drawings of objects and symbols displayed on irregular polygonal bases.  Taken together, the works refer to various kinds of transformation; the evolutionary transformation of primate to human; the transformation of one’s body through physical objects or activity; and the oppositional forces of nature and culture.

Haendel also utilizes both gallery and digital spaces to activate the work on view. In the gallery, black-and-white checkered patterns bisect the floor, interspersed by polygonal bases displaying still life drawings with hand-drawn QR codes, which link to a curated selection of YouTube videos chronicling physical transformation, such as a weight loss journey or the transition from male to female.

2nd Stop: DRISCOLL BABCOCK GALLERY (525 W 25th St) presents:  Margaret Bowland: Power

features 8 new paintings, which marry canonical imagery with contemporary references to blur fact and fiction, challenge cultural hierarchies, and offer alternate narratives. The exhibition also includes Bowland’s first major installation: a transformational bramble of US dollar bills folded into origami roses that twist throughout the gallery on barbed-wire stems, underscoring the dangerous allure of wealth and power.

Bowland’s paintings construct an anachronistic world dense with symbolic imagery. She employs a variety of sources, from the artistic production of the early modern Deccan plateau of India, to post-Renaissance European paintings, to today’s fashion magazine spreads. In this maelstrom of references, Bowland’s subjects bear the weight of complex power struggles, reckoning with enduring issues of race, gender and agency.

Symbols of privilege and status pervade each work. Money—perhaps the most obvious symbol of wealth—appears in various forms throughout: it surrounds Bowland’s subjects as it catches fire and burns; it creates, alongside fighter planes, an ironic, decorative fleur-de-lis pattern. In this way, wealth and prestige directly collide with war, violence, and destruction.

3rd stop: PACE  WIDENLSTEIN GALLERY (534 W 25th St) presents: Robert Rauschenberg: Anagrams, Arcadian Retreats, Anagrams (A Pun). 

the exhibition includes works from three series made during the mid-1990s into the 2000s, where the artist revisited image transfer techniques which he first explored on a smaller scale in the 1950s and 1960s. Using water-soluble inkjet dyes on paper, plaster, and polylaminate surfaces, Rauschenberg made digital color transfers from his photographs. Revealing the artist’s global perspective, the images are often derived from the photographs he took during his extensive international travels. Imagery for the Arcadian Retreats is largely derived from photographs he took in Turkey when he attended the United Nations Conference on Human Settlements (Habitat II) in 1996. With images transferred manually using a burnishing implement, the artist’s hand is revealed, resulting in painterly and subtly lyrical works.


4th stop: GAGOSIAN GALLERY (555 W 24th St) presents: ZENG FANZHI, PAINTINGS, DRAWINGS, AND TWO SCULPTURES

Zeng is at the forefront of a generation of Chinese artists who have achieved national and international prominence in the wake of the Cultural Revolution of the 1970s. Over the past three decades he has probed the place of the unconscious in the construction of human experience while reflecting on the collective national psyche in the face of broad and accelerated change. In his formative years, he was particularly inspired by the works of German Expressionism and French Romanticism, in which he found precedents for exploring the psychology of selfhood in the throes of societal flux. His searing Hospital Triptych No. 1 (1991), an early example of his virtuosic application of historical styles and techniques to interpret contemporary national realities, was shown in the pivotal exhibition “China's New Art, Post-1989” at the Hong Kong Arts Center in 1993.

With time, Zeng has tempered the direct impact of Western Expressionism with the local influence of traditional guohuapainting methods. His eloquent and confrontational work is charged with melancholy, unfolding in a succession of dystopic themes, both introspective and overtly socially critical.

5th stop: MARY BOONE GALLERY (541 W 24th St) presents: PETER SAUL, SIX CLASSICS

At age 81 and with 800 paintings to his credit, New York-based painter Peter Saul’s work is as fresh, singular, and thought-provoking as it ever has been.


“I know it’s a bit of an awful thing to say, but I really just make things up,” says Saul. “My main goal is to make a picture that people find interesting to look at and that has my name on it.”

His work is bright, bold, and abstract. Sometimes the paintings are cartoonish and grotesque, sometimes they are realistic and elegant. Despite the paintings’ absurdities, there is startling notions of truth in them. A strong sense of humor and unabashed love for painting always breathe through the canvases. But few artists have ever developed a style as instantly identifiable as Peter Saul.

Saul’s most recent exhibition at Mary Boone Gallery, Six Classics, finds the artist re-imagining six masterpieces from art history. Paying heed to his time as a wide-eyed young artist living in Paris in the late ’50s and ’60s, Saul recreates Alexandre Cabanel’s ‘The Birth of Venus’ (Musée d’Orsay, Paris), Jacques-Louis David’s ‘Napoleon Crossing the Alps’ (versions at the Château de Malmaison and the Palace of Versailles), Hyacinthe Rigaud’s full-length portrait ‘Louis XIV’ and Théodore Géricault’s ‘The Raft of the Medusa’ (both in the Louvre). With a rendition of Emanuel Leutze’s ‘Washington Crossing the Delaware,’ Saul examines two centuries of American sovereignty.

6th stop:  ANDREA ROSEN GALLERY (525 W 24th St) presents: Alina Szapocznikow, New Sculptures

On the heels of a major international traveling retrospective, this exhibition presents a meticulously assembled group of major figurative sculptures from the 1960s and 1970s. Ardently concentrating on life-size freestanding figures, these works represent some of the artist’s most significant bodies of work, lent from museums and private collections from around the world.

Szapocznikow, over the distilled course of fifteen years, developed a profound pioneering vision and formal language tensioned between lust and sexuality, and the threat of destruction. Embodying this dichotomy, her work contains an intense vividness of life that perhaps can be drawn to her personal history, surviving a youth in concentration camps; like a number of artists of her time, such as Paul Thek and Hannah Wilke, who came out of intensity, there is an incredible rigor and vibrance driven from the force of life.

At once seductive and unsettling, Szapocznikow’s work is often made from direct impressions and casts of body parts, each an attempt to fix the traces of the body and record the fleeting moments and absurd paradoxes of life. She infused a completely new set of materials: those she concocted and heavily documented in the laboratory of her studio—such as tinted polyester resin and polyurethane expanding foam—creating a post-human form of lamps that used casts made directly from her lips, to every day resources—pantyhose, newspaper clippings, photographs, with straw and resin, grass and foam—resulting in distinctly radical hybrids of the organic and inorganic.

7th stop: METRO PICTURES (519 W 24th St) presents: CAMILLE HENROT, New Works

 programmed self-help hotlines, which the artist developed in collaboration with writer Jacob Bromberg.

Instead of asking if we need help scheduling an appointment or rebooking a flight, Henrot’s hotlines, for example, prompt us to “press 5 if your dog manipulates you with lies, contradictions or promises.” Guiding you through a labyrinthine series of inane questions, the voice on the other end transforms from the trusted authority into the patronizing patriarch or shaming schoolteacher. In this parodic exaggeration of the frustrating nature and absurdity of automated hotlines, Henrot questions who within a society is an authority, why we accept them as such, and asks why we submit to being held hostage to these systems while waiting for a desired outcome.

As viewers dial their way through the dizzying hotline, which at first amuses but ultimately exasperates, we are left with a sense of disappointment. We are disappointed because the authority, “the man in charge,” has finally failed to meet our expectations.

Henrot’s new watercolor drawings represent anthropomorphic animal figures to illustrate unjust, unfair and abusive scenes taken from sources ranging from mythology to gossip blogs. The imagery recalls the disturbing actions and remorseless characters familiar in cartoons and comics. Similar to those genres, Henrot employs human-like animals with a sparring and winsome style, which in Henrot’s drawings evokes Modernist painters like Matisse and cartoonists such as Saul Steinberg. In one drawing, a happy couple stands casually as their unborn child bursts from inside the belly of a parent—the figure’s sex left undefined—to reveal it’s grimacing face, while in another, a pelican father stands with a snide expression in his eyes as he eats his young.

8th stop: GLADSTONE GALLERY (515 W 24th St) presents: Carroll Dunham, New Works

 nine large-scale paintings drawing on the nude bathers and pastoral landscapes familiar from Dunham’s works since the late 2000s. The new paintings show the evolution of the artist’s bathers, while making room for new subjects to enter the frame and complicate the visual terrain, including animals and a nude male figure introduced here in paintings for the first time.


Throughout his career, Dunham has developed images that would become paintings through drawing. For the first time, this exhibition will show a suite of such studies, for Horse and Rider (My X), alongside the painting. Arranged chronologically, the graphite drawings reveal the evolution of Dunham’s motifs and compositions over a period of two years. In addition to elucidating the development of the painting, the works demonstrate the strength and range of Dunham’s drawing practice.


9th Stop: BRYCE WOLKOWITZ GALLERY (505 W 24th St) presents:  STEPHEN WILKES, DAY TO NIGHT

Day to Night is an ongoing global photographic project that began in 2009. Working from a fixed camera angle, Wilkes captures the fleeting moments of humanity and light as time passes. After 24 hours of photographing and over 1500 images taken, he selects the best moments of the day and night. Using time as a guide, all of these moments are seamlessly blended into a single photograph in post-production, visualizing places that are part of our collective memory.
  Wilkes sees the camera not only as a device used to capture images, but also as an instrument to collect information.


10th stop: GALARIE RICHARD  (514 W 24th Sreeet) presents:  LI WEI, PHOTOGRAPHS

 ten selected photo-performances Li Wei has staged between 2000 and 2012 in China and worldwide. They attest the variety and the universalism of his subjects and his exceptional creativity beyond limits. Li Wei’s art is made for New York City, the city of Batman and Spiderman, a city for competitors that go further than anybody else to make the difference. Like Leonardo da Vinci who invented a flying machine for humans, Li Wei works deal with the concept of escaping physical gravity. They can be frightening like the feeling of falling (Icarus) and the feeling of vertigo. They can be liberating with the pleasant feeling to fly. His photographs can be humorous with a reverse gravity pushing you up. They open you to all possibilities like running on the sea or standing on a cloud like gods and saints in religious paintings. The show displays some of his first works representing the artist’s head floating in space. Two of them relate a relationship between him and a young woman.


Li Wei's art is a difficult and complex process mixing acrobatics and photography. Floating in the air, on the top of a skyscraper, or falling upside down from the sky, with his head embedded into the ground, the Chinese artist mobilizes cranes, helicopters, scaffoldings and thin steal wires to be tied on his ankles and/or other parts of his body to hold himself up or catch himself not falling down to achieve his preconceived perfect images. Only the wires and scaffolding that keep Li Wei's body suspended have been cropped out of the photos with Photoshop.  


11th stop: PAULA COOPER GALLERY (529 W 21st St) presents: JUSTIN MATHERLY, New works

12th stop: TONYA BONAKDAR GALLERY (521 W 21st St) presents: MARK MANDERS, SELECTED WORKS

Mark Manders' sculptures and installations present a surreal space wherein contradictions co-exist: the past and the future, the temporary and the permanent, the beautiful and the grotesque, the tender and the brutal. In the current exhibition, the viewer experiences the artist’s studio in the ground floor gallery, while the upstairs presentation moves the work to a place beyond its origin. This range of new sculptures highlights the juxtaposition of carefully rendered figurative elements, architectural fragments and altered everyday materials, thrusting the world we know into sharp contrast and heightening our perceptual understanding. This ongoing “self-portrait,” like chapters in a non-linear autobiography, gives physical form to a dreamlike psychological space where each object is rendered with subtle alteration of scale or other detail: a chair back made of painted fictional newspaper, figurative elements realized smaller or larger than human scale. Universally familiar terms such as "dog," "head," and "chair" are realized as objects combined to create abstract sentences. Produced through an intimate logic, the works appear at once just made and also enigmatically atemporal.


13th stop: GLADSTONE GALLERY (530 W 21st St) presents: JEAN TINGUELY, SCULPTURAL WORKS from[masked]


works by the artist from 1954 through 1991. Salvaged pieces of iron and wheels collected from junkyards provided abstract shapes for the artist. Using these “forms” and incorporating other found objects, Tinguely welded and assembled sculptures, creating a new function with the byproducts of consumption. He installed old motors, often decommissioned from 78rpm phonographs, onto his sculptures to produce unpredictable and non-repeating motion. Within these dynamic sculptures of chance, accident, and inconsistency, Tinguely’s sculptures often entertain or agitate the audience with their humor and irony. Tinguely is perhaps best known in New York for his monumental self-destroying sculpture Homage to New York, presented for only one evening in March of 1960 in the sculpture garden at MoMA.

The earliest work on view in the show will be Tinguely’s Meta-Malevich relief from 1954, whose title references constructivist compositions. A hidden pulley and rubber band system behind the pictorial plane moves white geometric shapes in front of the black background in non-repeating arrangements.


14th stop: GAGOSIAN GALLERY (522 W 21st St) presents: JEFF KOON, GAZING BALL PAINTINGS

In this series, Koons is in dialogue with artists of the past, such as Titian, El Greco, Courbet, and Manet, among others. The works deal with the power of artistic gesture. Each work has a blue glass gazing ball that sits on a painted aluminum shelf attached to the front of the painting. The viewer and the painting are reflected in the gazing ball. This metaphysical occurrence connects the viewer to a family of cultural history in real time. Through the simple act of placing a gazing ball in front of the images, painting and sculpture are reunited for maximum sensory perception, as in ancient times.


15th Stop: JONATHAN LeVINE GALLERY (529 W 20th St) presents: MARTIN WHITTFOOTH, OFFERINGS


In Wittfooth’s allegorical narratives, animals roam a dystopian world void of human life with the remnants of industrialized society in a state of devastation. Fires rage and oceans surge but despite the destruction, his creatures radiate and evoke a sentiment of oneness. Where they exist life flourishes and the animals in this sense are the life-givers.

The works in Offering explore the theme of shamanism and its current revitalization around the world. Wittfooth delves into the notion that the rediscovery of shamanistic practices, such as reaching an altered state of consciousness, is peeling away our egos and materialistic obsessions and encouraging a connection with nature and to each other.


16th stop:  MICHAEL ROSENFELD GALLERY [masked]th Ave @ 19th St) presents: METAL: American Sculpture,[masked]

FEE: $5.00 payabale in cash or VENMO to your tour guide Joey


Full paid members: FREE

After the event, we'll grab beers/wine and burgers (veggie options too!) at NY BURGER CO. on 23rd/10th
results.name: GUY GALLERY WALK: NOVEMBER 2015

These games are geared towards advanced to intermediate players.

Teams are divided by two team captains (captains pick players in turns in an attempt to keep teams balanced and competitive)

Physical play is allowed as long as it isn't overly aggressive or dirty.

Slide tackles are allowed only to block a shot on goal or to intercept a pass  NO slide tackling on a player with the ball.

Ball hogging is absolutely not tolerated

Keep in mind as we don't have permit, we need to be flexible.

results.description:
Photographer & Model Photoshoot Society Presents:

"Model & Workflow Series with Stephanie Dec - Nov. 14th"

This month we are presenting another new type of shooting experience called the Model & Workflow Series. In a nutshell, this shoot will go through the stages of setting up a model shoot, shooting and processing. We'll go from positioning lights, metering, model rapport, shooting a model, time management and then we'll do some post processing on the current shoot.

Objective:

During our bigger group shoots, lighting and metering is usually done beforehand. This shoot will go into the Why's, How's and methodology when setting up a "set". Lighting and Metering will be explained with actual application during our shoot. As this shoot will be limited to a small group, there will be more time to shoot a model but we'll use that time to work on rapport, time management and visualizing a concept with the model to get the shots you need to get a full set from a look. During the post processing portion, we will take some of the shots from the shoot and go through some simple preliminary adjustments onto some of the common issue we can solve when doing a studio shoot. (Example: background extension, seamless background crease smoothing, adding catch lights, color correcting, erasing tags, skin smoothing, dodge/burn usage, etc.) These issues will be relevant only to the looks we just shot so it's an actual application of solutions to a shoot we can all go back and practice on. (Because we all have different cameras and sensors, there will be unique issues to solve and you'll be presented with a more personalized solution.)

About the Shoot:

Stephanie is an amazing model who has become one of our member favorites over the few months she has been at the studio. She gives her all and we always get amazing photos with her. We planned out 3 glamour looks to shoot, including lingerie, sporty sexy and an edgier look. With these looks we will shoot high key, 3 light setup and either an outdoor or natural light/constant light mix. (Weather permitting)

The first two hours will be the actual shoot. We will take a half hour break for any one on one time with Stephanie and for a snack break before starting the post processing portion. (This will also give me and any photographer that brings a laptop a chance to prep the photos from the shoot earlier that we will work on.) Feel free to bring your laptops to follow along. If you are on a Mac, bring a flash drive and I can copy over any actions that may be of help from the processing workflow.

RSVP/Cost:

For new members: Please take the time to read the info below about how the Meetup is organized and how the shooting parameters are setup.


Please take a look/adhere to the Signup info below in the Disclaimers section as this will be enforced.

Cost: $80

(Cash preferred, Credit Cards/Paypal ok with $5 added for surcharge)

(Non-Commercial Release provided onsite or PDF version to email registered upon check-in.)

Model:

Stephanie Dec: MM#[masked]

(Photos provided by model for promotional purposes only. All rights their respective owners.) 

One-on-One: The model will be available for one half hour one on one shoot after the first two hours in the Meetup. If you want to pre-book time before the shoot, send me a message.

NEW Shared One-on-Ones: We are also implementing a system that has been working for the past few Meetups. It's the sharing of a half hour one on one with a fellow photographer. It can be shared together for the whole half hour or 15 minutes each photographer. 

____________________________________________________________________

About the Studio:

The studios is a beautiful 3,000 sq. ft., climate controlled,  fully functional studio. (Professional in-house lights, props, various seamless backdrops, actual commercial photography sets, kitchen, waiting room, meeting/presentation room, the works!) It's conveniently located to major highways and a 20-30 minute public transportation ride to and from NY.

About The Meetup Format:

We will keep the group small although we have the space to accommodate a big group. This keeps things from feeling rushed and overwhelming. Each photographer will have a set amount of time per look. This will allow you to  shoot as you would in an actual client shoot and not have to worry about the number of shots you are taking. (This proved to be ideal in our previous shoots as far as being able to get "the shot" and enough time to do so. Think of it as a mini one-on-one time with the model.) During the shoot we may opt to give a theme a direction to shoot for. As it would be for an actual client. (Ex: If the setup calls for a "cover shot" then it will give you a direction to aim for and to consider what equipment to use or what mood to capture.) No worries, bring what lens or lenses you have, you'll learn to use what you have for best results. We strive to bring forth real world conditions and parameters so there is a methodology to a setup or theme.

Check-in Procedure and Disclaimers:

Check-in - When you arrive, there will be a quick check-in. This will mostly be so you can read and adhere to the studio/group shoot guidelines and make payment for the shoot before we start. This will also let us send you the release forms in PDF format if we don't have physical copies available.

Releases - We will have one non-commercial release signed by the model through the studio only. (No additional releases will be signed.) If you need a commercial release signed, you can make arrangements with the model directly. Additional compensation for this is between the model and photographer.

Right to Refuse - We have the right to refuse a member's RSVP to the Meetup. It's a small community and models keep detailed info on photographers also. If we feel there is justifiable reason to refuse a RSVP, we will exercise that right.

Signups - Please signup when you know you will attend. If the signup passes the point to book another model and then we get no shows it's not fair to your fellow photographers who would be on a waiting list. It also puts the organizers in a tough spot, financially after booking an additional model to compensate for a bigger group. So, at the very least give us 3 days notice that you will not be able to attend or in case of no show, we will have to remove you from the group. When emergencies come up past the 3 days notice, followup with an email and we can make exceptions on a case by case basis. 

Model Cancellation - If a model cancels or a last minute model change occurs, you will have the option to cancel beforehand or not attend the Meetup on the day of, if it happens upon arrival to the Meetup.

Waitlist - When you are on a wait list, please be mindful as this is also considered a RSVP of availability. So, if we add another model or someone cancels within the 3 days before the shoot, your wait list status may upgrade to a "Yes". Please be on the lookout for updates on the Meetup page as Meetup sometimes takes longer to notify of a status change.

Updates - Updates will be made on this page up to the date of the Meetup or the night before. Emails will also be sent but Meetup emails are not always reliable to be sent to a receiver right away. (I've heard of emails arriving 3 hours later if at all.)

Postponements - Weather considerations will be made the night before a shoot or on the day of and the Meetup page will be updated as well as emails sent if a postponement occurs due to inclement weather or some other emergency. Lack of minimum RSVP to hold the event will also cause postponement of the shoot. The night before we would make the call wether to postpone so be on the look out for our email and Meetup page updates.

Any questions please email me at [masked]

results.description:
Basic Ground Rules for Participation

Please wear either a blue/black or white shirt to make things easy (Preferably bring both in case we need to mix the teams more evenly).


no need to respond at all if you can't/don't want to play

• if you do respond IN, please come unless something really urgent comes up (hangovers or better offers from your cooler friends not accepted for absences!)


• If you suck at Ultimate... you are more than welcome. This is open to ALL skill levels, ages etc. If you're really good, please pretend you suck every once in a while for the benefit of the rest of us! We're just here to run around and have fun. We all want to score and win but if you want to win at all costs, this is not the game for you.

• The trick with this group is making sure we have enough to play, so those who do show up don't waste a trip, so please make the effort this year to be honest with yourself and us about if you can/want to come down so we can make the right call for GAME ON or GAME OFF. If you are a "maybe" please indicate that via the comment section with a brief explanation (ie 80% chance I'll be there...). If you RSVP and are then unable to attend, please update your RSVP as soon as possible.

What is Ultimate Frisbee? In a nutshell <borrowed from Wiki> :

Ultimate is a limited-contact team field sport played with a disc (frisbee). Points are scored by passing the disc to a teammate in the opposing end zone. Other basic rules are that players must not take steps while holding the disc (maintain a pivot), and interceptions and incomplete passes are turnovers.

Closest analogy I could come up with = a mix of basketball and football, but played with a frisbee. You do not need to be an expert frisbee player/thrower etc. - it's all about having fun.
results.name: NEW TIME - Saturday Ultimate Frisbee (Anderson Park)

NYC Safe Energy Campaign presents an exciting and thought provoking afternoon:

Come to listen, to talk. We'll have a musician and a storyteller, and we want to hear your stories. What events have happened to you or your family, to your home, to the people in your world in these changing times? What dreams are you having? We’re all in this together. Let’s share with one another.


This event is free and open to everyone. Snacks will be provided.

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
The LOWER EAST SIDE ECOLOGY CENTER is in EAST RIVER PARK in the red brick two-story building known as the FIRE BOAT HOUSE.

Directions:

Subway: F or J to ESSEX/DELANCEY, stay on the downtown side of the street, walk toward the FDR DRIVE, cross the PEDESTRIAN BRIDGE at Delancey Street over the highway. You will see the FIRE BOAT HOUSE on the left just before the big ballfield.

Bus: M14A or the M22 bus to the last stop: GRAND STREET/FDR DRIVE. Walk south on the FDR service road to CHERRY STREET. Enter CORLEARS HOOK PARK, walk past the flagpole, cross the PEDESTRIAN BRIDGE, and look north for the FIRE BOAT HOUSE just behind the ballfield.

10v10, 75min+ game. Arrive early to warm up, and be ready to start at 2:00pm.


ALL players need to bring a white and black t-shirt and  ball.


It's a large field and some players may need the option to sub. If you're a dedicated goalkeeper let us know - Intermediate level.


****************************************************************

DETAILS:

• Played in a friendly environment. Pass the ball have fun.

• No rough tackles or play. Players are expected to bring a positive attitude, no screaming at/or berating team mates.

•  BRING A BALL. If you hit a ball into the river, you'll need to replace it!  If there aren't any dedicated goalkeepers playing, we rotate in goal every 5 mins.

• No metal cleats. Only turf or molded cleats.

• If you arrive late, pls wait until a break in the game. Inserting players in the middle of the game disrupts the flow, and it's not fair to those that arrive on time.


Payment goes toward field permit, equipment and fees.

See you at the pitch!


Note: The is a 2/3 regulation size field with full size goals. Not suitable for beginner level or inexperienced players.

By joining this group and attending events you agree to the Waiver Of Liability.

This Event:

The aim of this weekly event is to offer a place where Python developers and learners can come and ask questions or give help.

Individuals of all programming skill levels are welcome.

It is suggested that you bring your own laptop. If you don't have access to a laptop and want to attend, please let Paul Logston know and he will see about getting you a laptop for the day.

This event is free.

This event is not a tutorial. Tutorials hosted by Learn Python NYC are labeled as tutorials.

Resources:

Here are some learning resources and free text editor / IDE suggestions.

https://github.com/logston/NYCPythonSOH/blob/master/resources.rst

Detailed Directions to us:

As you enter the building located at 568 Broadway, New York, NY 10012 you will need to provide ID and your destination (Fueled Collective, 11th Floor) to the front desk. They will provide you with a sticker badge. Take one of the elevators (located to the right of the front desk) to the 11th floor. We will be in the Deerbrook conference room.

This month we read through Berlioz Symphonie Fantastique, which was schedule for October but canceled due to low pre-registration. We're going to do it this time!!

We try to hold these play-ins once per month on Saturdays for those who cannot make weekly rehearsals on Wednesday evenings and/or for those whose sections are full in the Wednesday night orchestra.


No need to practice ahead of time, only if you want to. Just come and have fun playing amazing music with other people!


Visit http://newsymphony.org/readingorchestra.html for more information, to pre-register, and to print out music. Bring your instrument and a music stand.

New Registration Fee is $10 for everyone, to help cover the cost of renting the hall and administrative costs. If you cannot pay the registration fee let me know and we will work something out, as we never want money to come in the way of playing music with others.

Will there be a yoga mat for me ? 

No, you should bring your own yoga mat or a towel or a blanket. Whatever is available.

Can I text or call the Organizer ?

Yes, if you have a question which is not answered in here, you can text or call him.

[masked] 

Oh, OK. Let me RSVP then but i'm not sure if i'm going to make it there.

Well, RSVP only if you are really going to make it to the class. 
Besides emergency situations, members who RSVP and don't show up will be removed from the group.

I'm not sure if i can make it on time. Can I come later ?

Short answer is NO.We encourage everyone to attend the classes which are free. All you need to do is come on time.  

What kind of yoga class this will be ?

It's based on Patanjali's 8-limbs-system which is gentle yet very effective-take a look at  group reviews-. We will start with breathing & Bioenergy techniques, and continue with standing poses and other pose groups. Before meditation and deep relaxation, we will also have 5 min free time that you can practice any asana you would like. The Instructor will be helping with the postures. 

I am a beginner and i have never tried yoga before. Can i join you guys ?

Beginners are welcome !!! 

Great, how am i going to get there ? where do you guys meet ? 

LOCATION PICTURES ARE HERE(where we meet and practice):

ABOUT THE PROGRAM The NYC Community Kayak Pool Program will begin at Riverbank State Park on Saturday, November 15, 2014 and runs through the beginning of March 7, 2015. The program provides basic kayak training to the public through the New York State Department of Parks in an Olympic size pool overlooking the Hudson River. These weekly classes are to introduce students to kayak equipment and learn basic strokes and safety. The program relies on instructors / volunteers from the kayak community.

Head Instructor Lee Reiser donates his time throughout the season. Lee is an ACA Level II Certified Instructor. He are assisted by individuals with a wide range of experience and certifications from the American Canoe Association and the British Canoe Union, two of the major organizations for the sport of recreational kayaking.

results.description:
Please note this restaurant is CASH ONLY.

The Place: The only steak house in New York with a Michelin star, this is an old school place where waiters serve aged beef in a German beer hall setting.

Peter Luger has been named the best steakhouse in New York City by Zagat Survey for 30 years in a row.The Brooklyn location is known for its long wooden bar, and the "dining rooms have a Teutonic air, with exposed wooden beams, burnished oak wainscoting, brass chandeliers and weathered beer-hall tables."

In 2002, it was named to the James Beard Foundation's list of "America's Classics."

Menu is here:

http://peterluger.com/brooklyn-menu/

As always:

Please don't RSVP unless you are sure you can go. I do notice the people who RSVP and then cancel which really isn't fair to everyone else. I reserve the right to give priority to people who don't do this in the future. I'm not trying to be mean or anything but it makes it much harder for me when people take spots and then cancel either quickly or last minute. Obviously more notice is better but please try to only sign up (for waitlist as well) if you know you can come.

Also even if the meetup is full please do put your name on the waitlist. I always give priority to people on the waitlist if spots open up. I will also try to give an idea in advance if it looks like there might be more spots. Also, if there are a lot of people on the waitlist I will try to get more seats, although for reservations made far in advance I am unlikely to succeed. At very least it will let me know what kinds of restaurants are popular so I can schedule more of those in the future. Thanks.
